awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Exploring on-farm innovation, environmental change, and rural livelihoods in the US hop industry
awd_abstract_narration:
Agricultural technological development in North America has been largely directed by large companies controlling innovations in machinery, plant genetics, and agrichemicals. However, hop growing is one agricultural industry that confounds this model. Hops are an herb used in beer-making applications and many of the large Yakima Valley hop growers have invested both in local breeding programs and on-farm infrastructure innovations. The goal of this project is to understand the conditions under which some farmers research and develop their own agricultural technologies while others rely on outside research and to examine the innovations yielded by these diverging approaches to agricultural technologies. Hop farming in the United States offers a natural experiment to understand these differences. This project collects data from hop farmers through on-farm visits and in-depth interviews with farm owners and operators to better understand the social and applied scientific worlds of hop growing in the Northwestern and Midwestern United States. Doing so has the potential to help enhance understanding of how including farmers as research contributors may yield a more vibrant and sustainable agricultural and environmental future for farming in the United States.

Drawing on qualitative data collected through on-site interviews and on-farm participant observation, this project responds to two core research questions: (1) How do environmental and market pressures impact decisions about technologies used on the hop farm? (2) What comparative lessons do hop producers have for environmental and technical considerations in other agri-food regimes? Responding to these questions in the context of hop farmers’ novel agricultural practices yields insights into broad societal concerns about labor, culture, and environment at the human-technology frontier. This is especially evident when studying agricultural practices where genetic and mechanical technological innovation has widely been employed to the detriment of farmer profits and the social health of farming communities. The unique position of hop farmers as on-farm innovators yields insights for alternative futures for agricultural technologies in cognate industries. This project contributes to research discourses in both STS and environmental sociology by critically considering where expert agricultural scientific knowledge is produced and maintained, and by questioning who may be considered an expert in agricultural science, particularly plant science. The implications of these queries are important for science-based policy in agricultural and environmental sectors if such policies are to be both inclusive as well as evidence-based. This original research provides novel insights into potential environmental alternatives to conventional models for other agricultures of scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Agricultural plant science, infrastructure design, and crop marketing have, for nearly the last century, been the domain of Land-Grant Universities (LGUs) and large agro-pharmaceutical companies. We are quite familiar with many of the development techniques, strategies, and outcomes made by these institutions. In many cases, previous research shows that new innovations by these groups have had the unfortunate effect of "locking in" commodity growers, reducing their overall freedom to make decisions about their farms. Hop growers are one group of farmers that break this mold, many breed their own new hop varietals, some have designed their own implements, and a few even have ownership stakes in hop merchant companies. Do their practices in these areas differ from those of LGU's and outside corporations? If so, are the results meaningfully different for the farmers, farming communities, and environments in which they reside?

To address these questions, the researcher conducted in-depth interviews with 21 hop farmers, most including on-site farm visits where the researcher also took field notes and photographs of their operations. Data from this project show that the character and kinds of innovations being pursued on farm do differ from those conducted at LGU's and input companies. Hop growers’ innovations privilege farmer autonomy, have been integral to the improving financial sustainability of large hop farms, and have indirectly improved the environmental adaptive capacity of these same Northwest farms. However, the results have not always been equitably shared, and the many farmers able and willing to work at the vanguard of development have seen the most benefits. While smaller farmers, farmers in new geographies, and those in other countries have struggled to keep pace.

The implications for this project show that the inclusion of farmers as research collaborators and research partners as opposed to research recipients is a vital avenue for future projects looking to make new scientific knowledge that supports locally sustainable transitions from both an environmental and economic standpoint. However, it also highlights the continued social importance for these avenues of development to arise as public partnerships with career researchers.  When left alone, farmers in this project tended to pursue anti-competitive protections that limit uptake of new development in favor of immediate financial gains. This case study also highlights the importance of research in this vein, as studies in additional industries would have significant implications about the generalizability of these findings.

Research from this project was used to complete the researcher's doctoral dissertation and has resulted in publications in Journal of Rural Studies, Geoforum, and a book chapter in Environmental Justice in the Anthropocene, along with additional manuscripts currently under review at other scientific journals and multiple presentations at scientific meetings.
